answers.answer: I am not expert but I can tell you that my temperature is often below normal - 98.6. Many timesI have had a temperature in the mid 97 range and I was told not to worryabout it. I doubt that everyone always tests at 98.6 and my guess is that their mainconcern after your surgery would be a fever. That might indicate an infection which is probably one of the major risks of any surgical procedure. I wouldn't worry but I would keep an eye of it and any significant departures from your 97.2.This is from the Mayo Clinic.http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/body-temperature/AN01513"Question:For the last several days, my body temperature has been around 96.9 F  according to an oral thermometer. Should I be concerned about it being too low?- Betty / VirginiaMayo Clinic breast-health specialist Sandhya Pruthi, M.D., and colleagues answer select questions from readers.AnswerProbably not. Although normal human body temperature is usually stated as 98.6 F (37 C) orally, it actually ranges from 97.5 to 98.8 F (36.4 to 37.1 C). Some people have temperatures in the 96 F range and feel fine. Your body temperature is not considered dangerously low until it is below 95 F (35 C).Mild reductions in body temperature are often temporary and don't indicate a serious problem or condition. For example, your temperature normally is lower in the morning than in the evening. The most common cause of a lower-than-normal body temperature is exposure to cold. But occasionally, a low body temperature can indicate an underlying problem or condition, such as:* Underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism)* Diabetes* Adrenal gland insufficiency (Addison's disease)* Hypothalamus dysfunction* Liver failure* Kidney failure* Widespread infection (sepsis)* Excessive use of alcohol or illicit drugs* A side effect of certain medications, such as phenothiazines, barbiturates, opiates, clonidine, lithium and benzodiazepinesIf your low body temperature persists, consult your doctor"Mike

if you had outpatient surgery yesterday, how long did they keep you?I had a very large open procedure last November for removal of a football sized ovarian cyst and the ovary itself. In the hospital my temp ran low for two days. Came from the pain medications and the anesthesia.  It goes away.  This is my experience only and may not apply to you.

I am pretty sure they want you to monitor your temp for fever---a sign of infection. If it goes up to, say, 100, then yes, you should call the facility where you were treated. My own personal "Normal" body temp is 97.5....If I get to 99 I have a fever and feel sick. Everyone is different. Also, if you lost a lot of blood, anesthesia, shock, etc., all indicators of "lower" body temps. You are still in the "totally fine" zone.
